Award.AwardTitle: Monographic Studies in the Nectriaceae, Hypocreales: Nectria, Cosmospora, and Neonectria
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Nectriaceae (Hypocreales, Ascomycota) includes some of the most conspicuous and ubiquitous microfungi in natural ecosystems. These fungi are common in soils, decaying plant material, insects, and other fungi. While most species are saprobes, others are pathogenic on plants and insects or endophytes living in the leaves and trunks of living trees. This study will define the taxonomy of three major genera: Nectria, Cosmospora, and Neonectria. These genera are significant because they include several species that are widespread plant pathogens and potential biological control agents. Even though these genera are ubiquitous and diverse in natural and agricultural ecosystems, none of them have received modern monographic treatment.

This project will also increase the participation of minorities in biological sciences and advance graduate research at Howard University. In addition, this project will increase the available germplasm of fungi as cultures deposited in public institutions; increase biodiversity data available through digital databases; produce web-based identification keys for those using these fungi as indicators of tropical forest disturbance and working to control the diseases caused by these fungi; deposit into GenBank diagnostic DNA sequences of reliably identified fungi; and provide the basis for studies on the population biology of species of interest to plant pathologists.

Intellectual merit:

This project has made a significant contribution to describing and cataloging the diversity of one of the most abundant groups of fungi: the Nectriaceae (Hypocrales, Ascomycota). According to data produced by this project, nectriaceous fungi are amongst the most abundant and diverse groups of fungi as endosymbionts of stems of trees and in the soil; they are also very common in tropical forests. This project made significant advances in the taxonomy of Neonectria, Cosmospora and Nectria. This project has described so far five new genera and more than 40 new species. More new species and genera are still in the process of being described.

The genera that were studied in this project resulted to encompass several other genera. Thus, in this project, Nectria was divided into three genera (Nectria, Allantonectria and Pleonectria); Neonectria into five genera (Ilyonectria, Rugonectria, Thelonectria, Campylocarpon and Neonectria); and Cosmospora into several other genera whose descriptions are still in progress. This is significant because some economically important species that were thought to belong in one genus really belong in another. For example, the canker-causing species belong in Neonectria, whereas the fungi that cause root rots belong in Ilyonectria and not in Neonectria as previously thought.

Another interesting finding, which is revealed for the first time for this group of fungi, is that some groups in the genus Cosmospora prefer to parasitize certain species of fungi, this means that many Cosmospora species are host-specific. These results also suggest that there was coevolution between Cosmospora species and their fungal hosts. This may have practical implications because if Cosmospora species were to be used in biological control of plant diseases caused by other fungi, it is necessary to use a species of Cosmospora that is specific to that fungal pathogen.

Broader impacts:

The loss of biodiversity due to land-use (e.g., deforestation) and climate changes is happening faster than the discovery, cataloging, and naming of fungi. The need to characterize fungal diversity and understand its role in native and novel ecosystems has created a sense of urgency in the scientific community to train more taxonomists. The main contribution of this project with regards to broader impacts, is the training of two graduate students and a post-doc in systematics of fungi. In addition, it provided PI Chaverri with the ability to continue with her systematics research (Chaverri as a Ph.D. student was also trained under a NSF-PEET project). One graduate student has finished her Ph.D. and has a job at the USDA also working with systematics of fungi important to agriculture. Another graduate student will finish in 2014. The post-doc that was trained in this project is doing another post-doc in Canada. The students and post-docs were very productive in publications, presentations in conferences, and in awards and recognitions. Thus, this project has accomplished the important goal of improving the scientific capacity to identify and catalog fungal species.

Besides training, this project produced 13 publications and many presentations at international and national professional conferences. Among publications, two comprehensive works (i.e. monographs) and an illustrated guide/book for the identification of "microfungi" are highlighted. Publications resulting from this project have many illustrations and keys for identification, which will aid users, such as ecologists and plant pathologists, to identify economically or ecologically important fungal species.
